70610.1007/706.1434-4475Monatshefte für Chemie - Chemical MonthlyAn International Journal of ChemistryMonatsh Chem0026-92471434-4475Springer ViennaViennas00706-015-1446-3144610.1007/s00706-015-1446-3Original PaperSynthesis and characterization of a novel two-dimensional samarium coordination polymer with pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, study of some optical propertiesTabatabaeeMasoumeh1aNateghiMohamad Reza1MohammadinasabReza2grid.466829.7Department of Chemistry, Yazd BranchIslamic Azad UniversityYazdIrangrid.466821.f0000000404940892Department of Chemistry, Kerman BranchIslamic Azad UniversityKermanIrantabatabaee@iauyazd.ac.ir8420151020151461016411647252201561020142522015842015© Springer-Verlag Wien 20152015Abstract

A new 2D Sm(III) coordination polymer, [Sm(µ-Hpzdc)(µ-pzdc)(H2O)3]n (pzdc2− = pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylate, Hpzdc− = pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylate protonated on N atom of pyarazine ring), has been synthesized by the reaction of pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, 4-amino-1H-1,2,4-triazole, and Sm(NO3)3·6H2O. The compound was characterized by infrared spectroscopy, elemental analyses as well as X-ray diffraction studies. The polymeric chains contain Sm(III) ions bridged by pzdc2− and Hpzdc− ions. Each pzdc2− and Hpzdc− ligands coordinate to Sm(III) ion as bidentate ligand in O,N fashion. Samarium(III) ion is nine coordinated by four O and two N atoms from two different pyz2− and two pyzH− ligands and three O atoms from water molecule in a distorted tri-capped trigonal prismatic [SmN2O7] arrangement. For possible optical applications, several important optical parameters such as absorption coefficient, refractive index, extinction coefficient, and dielectric constant were evaluated over the mid IR frequency range.

The preparation of organic–inorganic hybrid materials is an especially active research area in recent years. These materials could be applied in many fields, such as molecular recognition, adsorption and separation processes, catalysis, ion exchange, optical communication, and molecular magnetism [1–7]. Optical properties of any metal complex are important for optical applications, because optical properties are directly related with their structural and electronic properties [8]. Study of the optical constants together with their variation with frequency enables correlation to be made with the band structure derived by other method [9]. Several parameters such as bi- or multidentate bridging ligands, metal ions, temperature, pH, and solvent can influence the synthesis of one-, two-, and three-dimensional infinite metal coordination polymers. Bi- or multidentate bridging ligands containing N- or O-donors are used to bind metal centers, generating 1D, 2D, and 3D coordination polymers. The coordination chemistry of aromatic polycarboxylate metal complexes has attracted an interest as the potential bridging ligands with a variety of connection modes with metal centers and abundant structural motifs [10–13]. The coordination chemistry of different pyarazinecarboxylic acids (such as 2-pyarazinecarboxylic acid and pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid) has attracted an interest as the potential bridging ligands with a variety of connection modes with metal centers and abundant structural motifs [14–16]. pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid has two carboxyl groups that may be completely or only partly deprotonated. It can act as a bidentate chelating ligand through nitrogen and one carboxylate oxygen atom, while another carboxylate oxygen and heterocyclic nitrogen atoms can act as bridging atoms between metal ions to form coordination polymer [17, 18].

f-Block lanthanide ions have larger radii and higher coordination numbers than the transition metals and, therefore, they may generate coordination polymers with distinctive molecular structures and unusual properties. Recently, the synthesis of numerous lanthanide coordination polymers with benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid, benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid, and benzene-1,2,4,5-tetracarboxylic acid was studied [19–21], but little data are available on lanthanide group complexes containing pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid or 2-pyarazinecarboxylic acid [22, 23]. Samarium is an interesting choice of lanthanide metals for metal–organic-based polymers and forms coordinate complexes with high coordination numbers [24–26]. In continuation of our research on the synthesis and characterization of metal–organic frameworks with multi-carboxylate ligands [27–32], we report synthesis, characterization, and determination of optical constants of a new 2D samarium coordination polymer, [Sm(Hpzdc)(pzdc)(H2O)3]n (1), obtained from the reaction of Sm(NO3)3·6H2O, pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, and 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole.

Results and discussion

The coordination polymer, [Sm(Hpzdc)(pzdc)(H2O)3]n (1), was obtained by the reaction of Sm(NO3)3·6H2O with 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole and pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid in the molar ratio 1:1:1 at room temperature.

Crystal structure of complex

The complete coordination of the Sm atom and the coordination polyhedron around the cerium(III) ion are shown in Fig. 1 and a tri-capped trigonal prismatic geometry of Sm(III) ion is shown in Fig. 2. Figure 3 shows the 2D polymeric chain of 1, displaying the connectivity. The selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table 1 and the hydrogen bond geometry in Table 2.

The compound crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group P a b c. The structural analysis showed that there are two different pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylate ligands in the asymmetric unit (pzdc2− with two deprotonated carboxylate groups and Hpzdc− with two deprotonated carboxylate groups, but with a protonated N atom). As shown in Fig. 1, the Sm1 atom in 1 is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O4, O5, and O7), two nitrogen atoms from the four surrounding ligands and the nine coordination number is completed with three water molecules. Sm(III) is in the tri-capped trigonal prismatic geometry. Each sets of three oxygen atoms (O1, O5, O7) and (O4, O9, O11) form triangle around Sm(III) atoms and the angles between oxygen atoms (Table 2) demonstrate that they are approximately eclipsed. Therefore, a prism with tri-capped of two nitrogen (N2 and N3) and one oxygen atom (O10) on its faces is proposed (Fig. 2). Each pzdc2− or Hpzdc− ligand is coordinated to two Sm3+ ions in N,O,O′ fashion (N,O-chelated and monodentate O). As shown in Fig. 3, each metal ion connected to three neighboring ones, through carboxylate bridging groups of ligands. This coordination mode is responsible for the formation of two-dimensional polymer. The extensive O–H···O, O–H···N hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table 3) between O–H groups of water molecules, carboxylate groups of ligands, and heterocyclic nitrogen atoms contribute to the formation infinite three-dimensional framework (Fig. 4).

The Sm–O distances range from 2.369(3) to 2.532(3) Å and the Sm–N distances range from 2.740(4) to 2.778(4) Å in accordance with the values from the literature. The Sm–OC (from carboxylate) bond lengths vary from 2.369(3) to 2.395(2) Å and the Sm–OH2 distances vary from 2.427(3) to 2.532(3) Å. Sm–OC and Sm–OH2 distances agree well with that reported in other SmIII complexes [24–26, 33]. The value of Sm···Sm separation [7.753(1) Å] is longer than the reported in a dimeric Sm(III) complex, [Sm2(HBidc)3(H2O)]n, (4.1008 Å) [34] and 4.2461 (6) and 6.6506 Å for a samarium coordination polymer [24].

Optical constants of the thin film

Figure 5a, b shows the typical transmission and reflection spectra of thin films in the wavenumber range of 4000–400 cm−1. The transmittance and reflectance data can be analyzed to determine optical constants such as refractive index, absorption index, and dielectric constant. The refractive index is one of the most important optical parameters for materials design and technical applications. It includes valuable information for optical materials with higher efficiency. The changes in refractive index are important for controlling optical properties of the optical material-based metal complex studied.

The complex refractive index of the film can be expressed asn=n+ik\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$n = n + ik$$\end{document}where n and k are the real and imaginary parts of the refractive index. k is the extinction coefficient given byk=αλ/4π\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$k = \alpha \lambda /4\pi$$\end{document}where α is the absorption coefficient and λ is the wavelength. k is a measure of the fraction of light lost due to scattering and absorption per unit distance of the penetration medium. The plot of the variation of the extinction coefficient vs. energy of incident photons is shown in the Fig. 6a. It is seen that k values decrease with increasing wavenumbers and reach a nearly constant value. The refractive index of the film can be obtained from the following relation [35]:n=1+√R/(1-√R)\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$n = 1 + \surd R /(1 - \surd R)$$\end{document}where R is the reflectance. Figure 6b shows the variation of the refractive index vs. photon energy. The refractive index of a material is the key parameter for device design.

The complex dielectric constant is fundamental intrinsic material property. The real part of it is associated with the term that how much it will slow down the speed of light in the material and imaginary part gives that how a dielectric absorb energy from electric field due to dipole motion. The real and imaginary parts of the dielectric constant were determined using the following relation [36–39]:ε=εr+iεi=n+ik2\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\varepsilon = \varepsilon_{\text{r}} + i\varepsilon_{\text{i}} = \left( {n + ik} \right)^{2}$$\end{document}where εr and εi are the real and imaginary parts of the dielectric constant, respectively, and are given byεr=n2-k2andεi=2nk\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$\varepsilon_{\text{r}} = n^{2} {-}k^{2} {\quad{and}\quad}\varepsilon_{\text{i}} = 2nk$$\end{document}The variation of the real and imaginary dielectric constants (εr and εi) with energy is shown in Fig. 7. It is clear that the values of the real part of dielectric constant are more than the imaginary part due to small values of k2, while εi mainly depends on the k values which are related to the variation of absorption coefficients (Fig. 6). The variation of the dielectric constant with photon energy indicates that some interactions between photons and electrons are produced in this energy range.

Conclusion

A new 2D Sm(III) coordination polymer, [Sm(µ-Hpzdc)(µ-pzdc)(H2O)3]n (1), was prepared by the reaction of pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, 4-amino-1H-1,2,4-triazole, and Sm(NO3)3·6H2O. The typical transmission and reflection spectra of thin films in the wave number range of 4000–400 cm−1 were used for the first time to study several important optical parameters such as absorption coefficient, refractive index, extinction coefficient, and dielectric constant.

Experimental

All purchased chemicals were of reagent grade and used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded using FTIR Spectra JASCO 6300 spectrometer (KBr pellets, Nujol mulls, 4000–400 cm−1). Elemental analyses were performed using a Costech ECS 4010 CHNS analyzer.

X-ray crystallographic analysis

Data were collected on a Bruker Kappa APEX-DUO diffractometer using monochromated Mo-Kα radiation [38] and were measured using a combination of ϕ scans and ω scans. The data were processed using APEX2 and SAINT [38]. Absorption corrections were carried out using SADABS [40]. The structure was solved and refined using SHELXTL [41] for full-matrix least-squares refinement that was based on F2. H atoms were included in calculated positions and allowed to refine in riding-motion approximation with Uiso tied to the carrier atom. Figure 1 was drawn using SHEXTL [39]. The crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results for the compound are summarized in Table 1.

<italic>Poly[(μ</italic>-<italic>3</italic>-<italic>carboxypyridine</italic>-<italic>2</italic>-<italic>carboxylato)(μ</italic>-<italic>2,3</italic>-<italic>pyridinedicarboxylate)samarium(III)]</italic> (<bold>1</bold>, (C<sub>12</sub>H<sub>11</sub>N<sub>4</sub>O<sub>11</sub>Sm)<sub><italic>n</italic></sub>)

Pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid (0.336 g, 2 mmol) and 0.168 g 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole (2 mmol) were dissolved in 15 cm3 distilled water and refluxed for 2 h. Sm(NO3)3·6H2O (0.889 g, 2 mmol) was added to above solution and stirred at room temperature for 5 h. The precipitates were filtered off from the reaction mixture and the mother liquor was then kept at 4 °C. The colorless crystals of complex suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained after few days. IR (KBr): = 3400–3070 (b), 1713 (s), 1615 (s), 1565 (s), 1448 (s), 1168 (s), 1107 (s), 1066 (m), 884 (s), 839 (m), 649 (w) cm−1.

Sm(III) is in the tri-capped trigonal prismatic geometry. Each sets of three oxygen atoms (O1, O5, O7) and (O4, O9, O11) form triangle around Sm(III) atoms and the angles between oxygen atoms (Table 2) demonstrate that they are approximately eclipsed. Therefore, a prism with tri-capped of two nitrogen (N2 and N3) and one oxygen atom (O10) on its faces is proposed (Fig. 2). Each pzdc2- or Hpzdc- ligand is coordinated to two Sm3+ ions in N,O,O' fashion (N,O-chelated and monodentate O). As shown in Fig. 3, each metal ion connected to three neighboring ones, through carboxylate bridging groups of ligands. This coordination mode is responsible for the formation of two-dimensional polymer. The extensive O-H⋅⋅⋅O, O-H⋅⋅⋅N hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table 3) between O-H groups of water molecules, carboxylate groups of ligands, and heterocyclic nitrogen atoms contribute to the formation infinite three-dimensional framework (Fig. 4).The Sm-O distances range from 2.369(3) to 2.532(3) Å and the Sm-N distances range from 2.740(4) to 2.778(4) Å in accordance with the values from the literature. The Sm-OC (from carboxylate) bond lengths vary from 2.369(3) to 2.395(2) Å and the Sm-OH2 distances vary from 2.427(3) to 2.532(3) Å. Sm-OC and Sm-OH2 distances agree well with that reported in other SmIII complexes [24-26, 33]. The value of Sm⋅⋅⋅Sm separation [7.753(1) Å] is longer than the reported in a dimeric Sm(III) complex, [Sm2(HBidc)3(H2O)]n, (4.1008 Å) [34] and 4.2461 (6) and 6.6506 Å for a samarium coordination polymer [24].Optical constants of the thin filmFigure 5a, b shows the typical transmission and reflection spectra of thin films in the wavenumber range of 4000-400 cm-1. The transmittance and reflectance data can be analyzed to determine optical constants such as refractive index, absorption index, and dielectric constant. The refractive index is one of the most important optical parameters for materials design and technical applications. It includes valuable information for optical materials with higher efficiency. The changes in refractive index are important for controlling optical properties of the optical material-based metal complex studied.The complex refractive index of the film can be expressed as1n=n+ik\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$n = n + ik$$\end{document}where n and k are the real and imaginary parts of the refractive index. k is the extinction coefficient given by2k=αλ/4π\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$k = \alpha \lambda /4\pi$$\end{document}where α is the absorption coefficient and λ is the wavelength. k is a measure of the fraction of light lost due to scattering and absorption per unit distance of the penetration medium. The plot of the variation of the extinction coefficient vs. energy of incident photons is shown in the Fig. 6a. It is seen that k values decrease with increasing wavenumbers and reach a nearly constant value. The refractive index of the film can be obtained from the following relation [35]:3n=1+√R/(1-√R)\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$n = 1 + \surd R /(1 - \surd R)$$\end{document}where R is the reflectance. Figure 6b shows the variation of the refractive index vs. photon energy. The refractive index of a material is the key parameter for device design.The complex dielectric constant is fundamental intrinsic material property. The real part of it is associated with the term that how much it will slow down the speed of light in the material and imaginary part gives that how a dielectric absorb energy from electric field due to dipole motion. The real and imaginary parts of the dielectric constant were determined using the following relation [36-39]:4ε=εr+iεi=n+ik2\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$\varepsilon = \varepsilon_{\text{r}} + i\varepsilon_{\text{i}} = \left( {n + ik} \right)^{2}$$\end{document}where εr and εi are the real and imaginary parts of the dielectric constant, respectively, and are given by5εr=n2-k2andεi=2nk\documentclass[12pt]{minimal}     \usepackage{amsmath}     \usepackage{wasysym}     \usepackage{amsfonts}     \usepackage{amssymb}     \usepackage{amsbsy}     \usepackage{mathrsfs}     \usepackage{upgreek}     \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt}     \begin{document}$$\varepsilon_{\text{r}} = n^{2} {-}k^{2} {\quad{and}\quad}\varepsilon_{\text{i}} = 2nk$$\end{document}The variation of the real and imaginary dielectric constants (εr and εi) with energy is shown in Fig. 7. It is clear that the values of the real part of dielectric constant are more than the imaginary part due to small values of k2, while εi mainly depends on the k values which are related to the variation of absorption coefficients (Fig. 6). The variation of the dielectric constant with photon energy indicates that some interactions between photons and electrons are produced in this energy range.ConclusionA new 2D Sm(III) coordination polymer, [Sm(µ-Hpzdc)(µ-pzdc)(H2O)3]n (1), was prepared by the reaction of pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, 4-amino-1H-1,2,4-triazole, and Sm(NO3)3⋅6H2O. The typical transmission and reflection spectra of thin films in the wave number range of 4000-400 cm-1 were used for the first time to study several important optical parameters such as absorption coefficient, refractive index, extinction coefficient, and dielectric constant.ExperimentalAll purchased chemicals were of reagent grade and used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded using FTIR Spectra JASCO 6300 spectrometer (KBr pellets, Nujol mulls, 4000-400 cm-1). Elemental analyses were performed using a Costech ECS 4010 CHNS analyzer.X-ray crystallographic analysisData were collected on a Bruker Kappa APEX-DUO diffractometer using monochromated Mo-Kα radiation [38] and were measured using a combination of ϕ scans and ω scans. The data were processed using APEX2 and SAINT [38]. Absorption corrections were carried out using SADABS [40]. The structure was solved and refined using SHELXTL [41] for full-matrix least-squares refinement that was based on F2. H atoms were included in calculated positions and allowed to refine in riding-motion approximation with Uiso tied to the carrier atom. Figure 1 was drawn using SHEXTL [39]. The crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results for the compound are summarized in Table 1.Poly[(μ-3-carboxypyridine-2-carboxylato)(μ-2,3-pyridinedicarboxylate)samarium(III)] (1, (C12H11N4O11Sm)n)Pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid (0.336 g, 2 mmol) and 0.168 g 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole (2 mmol) were dissolved in 15 cm3 distilled water and refluxed for 2 h. Sm(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.889 g, 2 mmol) was added to above solution and stirred at room temperature for 5 h. The precipitates were filtered off from the reaction mixture and the mother liquor was then kept at 4 °C. The colorless crystals of complex suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained after few days. elements.content: A new 2D Sm(III) coordination polymer, [Sm(µ-Hpzdc)(µ-pzdc)(H2O)3]n (pzdc2− = pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylate, Hpzdc− = pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylate protonated on N atom of pyarazine ring), has been synthesized by the reaction of pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, 4-amino-1H-1,2,4-triazole, and Sm(NO3)3·6H2O. The compound was characterized by infrared spectroscopy, elemental analyses as well as X-ray diffraction studies. The polymeric chains contain Sm(III) ions bridged by pzdc2− and Hpzdc− ions. Each pzdc2− and Hpzdc− ligands coordinate to Sm(III) ion as bidentate ligand in O,N fashion. Samarium(III) ion is nine coordinated by four O and two N atoms from two different pyz2− and two pyzH− ligands and three O atoms from water molecule in a distorted tri-capped trigonal prismatic [SmN2O7] arrangement. For possible optical applications, several important optical parameters such as absorption coefficient, refractive index, extinction coefficient, and dielectric constant were evaluated over the mid IR frequency range.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new 2D Sm(III) coordination polymer, [Sm(µ-Hpzdc)(µ-pzdc)(H2O)3]n (pzdc2- = pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylate, Hpzdc- = pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylate protonated on N atom of pyarazine ring), has been synthesized by the reaction of pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, 4-amino-1H-1,2,4-triazole, and Sm(NO3)3⋅6H2O. The compound was characterized by infrared spectroscopy, elemental analyses as well as X-ray diffraction studies. The polymeric chains contain Sm(III) ions bridged by pzdc2- and Hpzdc- ions. Each pzdc2- and Hpzdc- ligands coordinate to Sm(III) ion as bidentate ligand in O,N fashion. Samarium(III) ion is nine coordinated by four O and two N atoms from two different pyz2- and two pyzH- ligands and three O atoms from water molecule in a distorted tri-capped trigonal prismatic [SmN2O7] arrangement. For possible optical applications, several important optical parameters such as absorption coefficient, refractive index, extinction coefficient, and dielectric constant were evaluated over the mid IR frequency range.

elements.content:
Introduction

The preparation of organic–inorganic hybrid materials is an especially active research area in recent years. These materials could be applied in many fields, such as molecular recognition, adsorption and separation processes, catalysis, ion exchange, optical communication, and molecular magnetism [1–7]. Optical properties of any metal complex are important for optical applications, because optical properties are directly related with their structural and electronic properties [8]. Study of the optical constants together with their variation with frequency enables correlation to be made with the band structure derived by other method [9]. Several parameters such as bi- or multidentate bridging ligands, metal ions, temperature, pH, and solvent can influence the synthesis of one-, two-, and three-dimensional infinite metal coordination polymers. Bi- or multidentate bridging ligands containing N- or O-donors are used to bind metal centers, generating 1D, 2D, and 3D coordination polymers. The coordination chemistry of aromatic polycarboxylate metal complexes has attracted an interest as the potential bridging ligands with a variety of connection modes with metal centers and abundant structural motifs [10–13]. The coordination chemistry of different pyarazinecarboxylic acids (such as 2-pyarazinecarboxylic acid and pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid) has attracted an interest as the potential bridging ligands with a variety of connection modes with metal centers and abundant structural motifs [14–16]. pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid has two carboxyl groups that may be completely or only partly deprotonated. It can act as a bidentate chelating ligand through nitrogen and one carboxylate oxygen atom, while another carboxylate oxygen and heterocyclic nitrogen atoms can act as bridging atoms between metal ions to form coordination polymer [17, 18].

Graphical abstract



Introduction

The preparation of organic-inorganic hybrid materials is an especially active research area in recent years. These materials could be applied in many fields, such as molecular recognition, adsorption and separation processes, catalysis, ion exchange, optical communication, and molecular magnetism [1-7]. Optical properties of any metal complex are important for optical applications, because optical properties are directly related with their structural and electronic properties [8]. Study of the optical constants together with their variation with frequency enables correlation to be made with the band structure derived by other method [9]. Several parameters such as bi- or multidentate bridging ligands, metal ions, temperature, pH, and solvent can influence the synthesis of one-, two-, and three-dimensional infinite metal coordination polymers. Bi- or multidentate bridging ligands containing N- or O-donors are used to bind metal centers, generating 1D, 2D, and 3D coordination polymers. The coordination chemistry of aromatic polycarboxylate metal complexes has attracted an interest as the potential bridging ligands with a variety of connection modes with metal centers and abundant structural motifs [10-13]. The coordination chemistry of different pyarazinecarboxylic acids (such as 2-pyarazinecarboxylic acid and pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid) has attracted an interest as the potential bridging ligands with a variety of connection modes with metal centers and abundant structural motifs [14-16]. pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid has two carboxyl groups that may be completely or only partly deprotonated. It can act as a bidentate chelating ligand through nitrogen and one carboxylate oxygen atom, while another carboxylate oxygen and heterocyclic nitrogen atoms can act as bridging atoms between metal ions to form coordination polymer [17, 18].

elements.content: f-Block lanthanide ions have larger radii and higher coordination numbers than the transition metals and, therefore, they may generate coordination polymers with distinctive molecular structures and unusual properties. Recently, the synthesis of numerous lanthanide coordination polymers with benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid, benzene-1,3,5-tricarboxylic acid, and benzene-1,2,4,5-tetracarboxylic acid was studied [19–21], but little data are available on lanthanide group complexes containing pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid or 2-pyarazinecarboxylic acid [22, 23]. Samarium is an interesting choice of lanthanide metals for metal–organic-based polymers and forms coordinate complexes with high coordination numbers [24–26]. In continuation of our research on the synthesis and characterization of metal–organic frameworks with multi-carboxylate ligands [27–32], we report synthesis, characterization, and determination of optical constants of a new 2D samarium coordination polymer, [Sm(Hpzdc)(pzdc)(H2O)3]n (1), obtained from the reaction of Sm(NO3)3·6H2O, pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, and 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole.

Samarium is an interesting choice of lanthanide metals for metal-organic-based polymers and forms coordinate complexes with high coordination numbers [24-26]. In continuation of our research on the synthesis and characterization of metal-organic frameworks with multi-carboxylate ligands [27-32], we report synthesis, characterization, and determination of optical constants of a new 2D samarium coordination polymer, [Sm(Hpzdc)(pzdc)(H2O)3]n (1), obtained from the reaction of Sm(NO3)3⋅6H2O, pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, and 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole.

Results and discussion

The coordination polymer, [Sm(Hpzdc)(pzdc)(H2O)3]n (1), was obtained by the reaction of Sm(NO3)3⋅6H2O with 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole and pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid in the molar ratio 1:1:1 at room temperature.

The compound crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group P a b c. The structural analysis showed that there are two different pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylate ligands in the asymmetric unit (pzdc2− with two deprotonated carboxylate groups and Hpzdc− with two deprotonated carboxylate groups, but with a protonated N atom). As shown in Fig. 1, the Sm1 atom in 1 is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O4, O5, and O7), two nitrogen atoms from the four surrounding ligands and the nine coordination number is completed with three water molecules. Sm(III) is in the tri-capped trigonal prismatic geometry. Each sets of three oxygen atoms (O1, O5, O7) and (O4, O9, O11) form triangle around Sm(III) atoms and the angles between oxygen atoms (Table 2) demonstrate that they are approximately eclipsed. Therefore, a prism with tri-capped of two nitrogen (N2 and N3) and one oxygen atom (O10) on its faces is proposed (Fig. 2). Each pzdc2− or Hpzdc− ligand is coordinated to two Sm3+ ions in N,O,O′ fashion (N,O-chelated and monodentate O). As shown in Fig. 3, each metal ion connected to three neighboring ones, through carboxylate bridging groups of ligands. This coordination mode is responsible for the formation of two-dimensional polymer. The extensive O–H···O, O–H···N hydrogen-bonding interactions (Table 3) between O–H groups of water molecules, carboxylate groups of ligands, and heterocyclic nitrogen atoms contribute to the formation infinite three-dimensional framework (Fig. 4).

elements.content: The Sm–O distances range from 2.369(3) to 2.532(3) Å and the Sm–N distances range from 2.740(4) to 2.778(4) Å in accordance with the values from the literature. The Sm–OC (from carboxylate) bond lengths vary from 2.369(3) to 2.395(2) Å and the Sm–OH2 distances vary from 2.427(3) to 2.532(3) Å. Sm–OC and Sm–OH2 distances agree well with that reported in other SmIII complexes [24–26, 33]. The value of Sm···Sm separation [7.753(1) Å] is longer than the reported in a dimeric Sm(III) complex, [Sm2(HBidc)3(H2O)]n, (4.1008 Å) [34] and 4.2461 (6) and 6.6506 Å for a samarium coordination polymer [24].

elements.content: Figure 5a, b shows the typical transmission and reflection spectra of thin films in the wavenumber range of 4000–400 cm−1. The transmittance and reflectance data can be analyzed to determine optical constants such as refractive index, absorption index, and dielectric constant. The refractive index is one of the most important optical parameters for materials design and technical applications. It includes valuable information for optical materials with higher efficiency. The changes in refractive index are important for controlling optical properties of the optical material-based metal complex studied.
elements.clean_text:
Optical constants of the thin film

Figure 5a, b shows the typical transmission and reflection spectra of thin films in the wavenumber range of 4000-400 cm-1. The transmittance and reflectance data can be analyzed to determine optical constants such as refractive index, absorption index, and dielectric constant. The refractive index is one of the most important optical parameters for materials design and technical applications. It includes valuable information for optical materials with higher efficiency. The changes in refractive index are important for controlling optical properties of the optical material-based metal complex studied.

elements.content: A new 2D Sm(III) coordination polymer, [Sm(µ-Hpzdc)(µ-pzdc)(H2O)3]n (1), was prepared by the reaction of pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, 4-amino-1H-1,2,4-triazole, and Sm(NO3)3·6H2O. The typical transmission and reflection spectra of thin films in the wave number range of 4000–400 cm−1 were used for the first time to study several important optical parameters such as absorption coefficient, refractive index, extinction coefficient, and dielectric constant.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A new 2D Sm(III) coordination polymer, [Sm(µ-Hpzdc)(µ-pzdc)(H2O)3]n (1), was prepared by the reaction of pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid, 4-amino-1H-1,2,4-triazole, and Sm(NO3)3⋅6H2O. The typical transmission and reflection spectra of thin films in the wave number range of 4000-400 cm-1 were used for the first time to study several important optical parameters such as absorption coefficient, refractive index, extinction coefficient, and dielectric constant.

elements.content: All purchased chemicals were of reagent grade and used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded using FTIR Spectra JASCO 6300 spectrometer (KBr pellets, Nujol mulls, 4000–400 cm−1). Elemental analyses were performed using a Costech ECS 4010 CHNS analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

All purchased chemicals were of reagent grade and used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded using FTIR Spectra JASCO 6300 spectrometer (KBr pellets, Nujol mulls, 4000-400 cm-1). Elemental analyses were performed using a Costech ECS 4010 CHNS analyzer.

elements.content: Data were collected on a Bruker Kappa APEX-DUO diffractometer using monochromated Mo-Kα radiation [38] and were measured using a combination of ϕ scans and ω scans. The data were processed using APEX2 and SAINT [38]. Absorption corrections were carried out using SADABS [40]. The structure was solved and refined using SHELXTL [41] for full-matrix least-squares refinement that was based on F2. H atoms were included in calculated positions and allowed to refine in riding-motion approximation with Uiso tied to the carrier atom. Figure 1 was drawn using SHEXTL [39]. The crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results for the compound are summarized in Table 1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallographic analysis

Data were collected on a Bruker Kappa APEX-DUO diffractometer using monochromated Mo-Kα radiation [38] and were measured using a combination of ϕ scans and ω scans. The data were processed using APEX2 and SAINT [38]. Absorption corrections were carried out using SADABS [40]. The structure was solved and refined using SHELXTL [41] for full-matrix least-squares refinement that was based on F2. H atoms were included in calculated positions and allowed to refine in riding-motion approximation with Uiso tied to the carrier atom. Figure 1 was drawn using SHEXTL [39]. The crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results for the compound are summarized in Table 1.

elements.content: Pyarazine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid (0.336 g, 2 mmol) and 0.168 g 4-amino-1,2,4-triazole (2 mmol) were dissolved in 15 cm3 distilled water and refluxed for 2 h. Sm(NO3)3·6H2O (0.889 g, 2 mmol) was added to above solution and stirred at room temperature for 5 h. The precipitates were filtered off from the reaction mixture and the mother liquor was then kept at 4 °C. The colorless crystals of complex suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained after few days.
